HERE IS FOR ANYONE WHO WANTS TO KNOW HOW WE SEE:


We see by a lens in the front of the eye that changes shape when looking at a closer object Or a farther object, once it goes from there, It goes to the pupil. Which changes shape depending on the brightness of the room, If it's darker the pupil will get bigger, letting more light in. Finally, the light gets hit to the back of the eye called the retina. The retina is covered in millions of light-sensitive receptors known as rods and cones. Each receptor contains pigment molecules, which change shape when they are hit by at least 9 photons, Triggering an electrical message that travels to the brain via the optic nerve. Rods work at low light to help to see darker things better, But they aren't good at color or depth, And Cones work for better color and depth, But don't work well with dark light. Our eyes are only able to produce two-dimensional images, but with some clever processing, the brain is able to build these flat pictures into a three-dimensional view. Our eyes are positioned about five centimeters (two inches) apart, so each sees the world from a slightly different angle. The brain compares the two pictures, using the differences to create the illusion of depth.

Light is oscillating electrostatic force carried by vibrating matter/medium/atoms/electrons.

Electrons are on the surface of all matters. Electrons are constantly vibrating due to the energy atom carries. The higher temperature the higher vibration frequency.

Line of sight electrons on the sun and the moon are repelling each other constantly with the force F=Ke x ee/rr. That force is the conductor/messenger of light/radiation. That force instantaneously transfer energy between electrons on the sun and moon.

Light speed in vacuum is infinite. Light only exist with matter/medium. Light speed in a medium is the rate of induction of electrostatic force.

All the light and EM waves in daily life are vibrating electrostatic force moving in matter, therefore light act as wave. Photoelectric effect is misinterpretation of the vibrating force as photon particles momentum.

There is no matter in space, no energy and wave in space, no force and field in space. Energy, force, field must co-exist with matter.

Photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) on the retina (the outermost layer on the inside of your eye) detect light by absorbing photons. The absorbed photons are converted to electrical signals (this is called phototransduction) that are passed through the optic nerve to the brain. The brain uses each signal, or speck of light/color (received from 4~5 mil cones and ~90 mil rods), to build an image, similar to how individual pixels make up your computer monitor display.

Normally, if you are in a dark room and a beam of light passes in front of you from left to right, you won't see it.

Seeing light, in the way we do, involves the photon being destroyed in the retina and the resulting energy causing an electrical signal to the brain (or, instead of retina and brain, it could be a detector and a computer).

This new method allows us to be aware that a photon exists without it's destruction.

Since a photon is simply a particle of light (that can act like a wave) it is impossible to observe or see the photon without absorbing and destroying it.  Think about it this way, if a photon enters the aperture of a camera, it is destroyed in order to record itself on the film, and the only way that we can directly observe this photon is if it enters the camera aperture.  So, it doesn't "know" that it is being watched, rather, watching a photon destroys it in order to watch it.

Clarification of the atom sent through a box bit:

The atom sent in is in a superposition of two states, so if there's no photon in the box, the atom comes out exactly how it went in, with a 50-50 chance of being measured in either state. If there is a photon, though, the atom interacts with it and is "pulled" into the photons state (kind of like stimulated emission, the principle behind lasers), so we don't see 50-50 odds upon exit. The odds are instead tilted in favor of the photon's state.

You have a particle that can either be in State A or State B. At first, it's in both at the same time. When you shoot it through the box, if it hit a photon it'll come out in State B most of the time. If it didn't hit a photon, it'll come out in State A most of the time. So if you shoot it through and it comes out in State A 90% of the time, there's no photon inside. If it comes out in State B 90% of the time, then there IS a photon inside. And that's how we see it :) .
